It's an interesting idea that yawning might be the body's way of reawakening when it has almost fallen into lethargy. Could well be true. My own favorite theory, though, is still that it was a signal for the entire flock of primitive nomadic humans to go to sleep at approximately the same time. It wouldn't be good for half the flock to keep trekking while the other half went to sleep. On the other hand, these theories should ultimately be aligned with what's happening in the animal kingdom - and I don't know whether there's a lot of studies done on yawning animals.

I've never understood the "cooling the brain" hypothesis. How much cooler does the brain really get from a yawn vs normal breathing? Enough to justify an involuntary behaviour? How would that have evolved? The hypothesis of equalising pressure across the ears makes more sense to me. Is there good counter-evidence ruling it out? Equalising pressure both protects your eardrums, and makes your hearing more sensitive, so there are good reasons to want to equalise pressure before you sleep and when you wake up, and if the whole tribe is moving up or down a mountain together, a social yawn can help keep everyone's hearing as keen as possible. In an evolutionary sense the benefits look obvious - yet it seems to be a very unpopular hypothesis. Why is that?
[ed] - I couldn't read that Ramirez study because it's paywalled, as are most of the other refs listed, but I don't find their abstract very convincing. it would be interesting to see the whole paper.

I really don't think this study made the right conclusion. I mean, they did find something, but it's not anything as interesting or new as it sounds. The increased alertness can just as well be explained as a result of the increased oxygen flow to the brain. It's also my own experience that, when I was in school I had a lung infection that affected my ability to get oxygen and as a result I would yawn a lot more.

The most likely reason for yawning is that it's an involuntary reaction when the body decides it needs more oxygen, since it works as a sort of purge to flush old air out of the lungs whilst at the same time bringing in more fresh air. It being a social response is secondary to that, as a by-product of it creating increased alertness, so it's beneficial to survival, rather than it being a direct purpose for yawning to exist like the study seemed to imply.
What i gleaned from this video is that we still don't know why we yawn. Sounds to me like this "study" set out to prove it's own conclusion.

Reflexive cursing is triggered by ancient circuitry in our brains... intended to give an audible alert to the detection of sudden danger... and in particular, snakes... because they are one of our most ancient threats when we were more more like primates... and, primates of today, use the same circuitry to give out particular calls that correlate to different threats... one of which is assigned to snakes on the ground, so they flee to the trees to avoid them. We've lost the specificity in ours... but it is fundamentally the same when you curse out of sudden fear, or sudden pain. And this circuitry likely is an element that malfunctions in those with Tourette Syndrome that exhibit Coprolalia behavior.

It may even be possible there is a link to the warning call and the mouth shape that resembles yawning... which would coincide with reflexive warnings like dog's tendency to reactively bark when they hear other barking. And other primates spread the call, to make sure they all get the alert.

I don't know why people act like we still don't understand yawning. There are several reasons that we yawn. Some of the reasons that we yawn are for acclimation and equalization. We're constantly inhaling air from the outer atmosphere into our internal environment which has a different pressure. As we slow down and get tired and get ready for bed or sit down our blood flow and our respiratory patterns slow down and change which also changes the pressure. We may even breathe more through our nose which increases the amount of CO2 that we actually take in. Yawning helps to create equilibrium. If you ever go on an airplane or up and down a hill and your ears get stuffed because they need to equalize they say to chew gum. That may help but the best thing to do is to make yourself yawn as deep as you can and breathe through your nose and your mouth while you do it. Your ears will most likely pop as you equalize with the atmospheric pressure. It is most definitely a way to get oxygen deep into your lungs and into your blood and your brain. Especially when your activity has slowed down, or you've increased activity and you're not inhaling enough oxygen. For instance if you start jogging you may actually yawn because you're using oxygen and your body has different ways to cope with that. People sometimes yawn when they jog. It's not necessarily because you're tired it's because your body is using more oxygen and because of the faster rate of breathing you have to equalize more properly. Yawning helps to push the air deep down into your lungs to equalize the pressure as well as create pressure to help push oxygen to be absorbed through your lungs. Somewhat similar to reverse osmosis or a semi-permanentable membrane/filter.

The studies with college students also went so far as to help find people who had sociopathic tendencies OR full-blown cases.

Those who have sociopathic and/or psychopathic personality types were generally found to NOT respond to yawning, a well-known social cue; primarily because a sociopath does not feel empathy for others ~ they feel only the need for self-gratification and fulfilling their own needs while outright ignoring others IN that search.

Really, a lot of dissertations and psychological proofs came out of these extremely interesting studies; we're still not finished with all the theories that still surround these social experiments!

Ive had a theory for many years now that yawning is a defensive tactic used to discourage attacks when you are tired and therefore less able to defend yourself. By showing your teeth, you remind potential attackers that they may get bit if they go after you. It also stands to reason that others in your group would be likely to yawn after you yawn and show their teeth also to further discourage attacks to the group while some of the group is less than fully alert. This makes sense with the evidence of ppl more quickly spotting danger after watching someone yawn. It also explains why some people yawn while getting into confrontations. Just a theory, but the best ive ever thought of and better than any I've heard yet.

Yawning is very old adaptation among social animals. It is a signal and reaction that initiated the group to settle together. Individuals, especially the young, that got tired and stopped to rest while the group moved on got ate. Individuals that continued on while the group settled to rest got ate. Contagious yawning helps to keep the group together and pass on their genes. Somebody write the grant proposal, do the research and write the papers.

I kind of feel like this hypothesis is leaning a bit too hard on correlation. There may be something to being more alert when you see someone else yawning from exhaustion, but that doesn't really translate well to the contagious nature. I'd think it'd rather do the opposite. If you had a dozen people together, and one person was tired and yawns, you quickly get yawns being passed among the whole group. In all but one instance those yawns according to this theory would indicate that the person observed was MORE aware of their surroundings, not less. Unless the idea is that person A yawns, that triggers person B to yawn, and person A seeing that contagious yawn gets kicked from stupor to instead heightened awareness instead of the lacking awareness they otherwise would have. But that seems a pretty sloppy  and roundabout way to get a yawn to increase your OWN awareness, when the process could instead be completely contained within the one person.

When you're focused or engaged, you tend to take smaller breaths, have irregular breathing and lack of deeper breaths can result in little hiccups, those are yawns. Yawning takes in a larger amount of air and opens all the airways that have been deprived from the outside air that previously have not been in use. You tend to breathe irregularly when you're more tired or when you're doing interesting but non-active things. For SciShow to say that the oxygen answer doesn't hold up to evidence is completely absurd, this is why you can't always believe what your source tells you, even if the source does their own research into the matter. I think science is looking for a specific answer when in fact, the very means of opening airways with a larger breath does a lot for the lungs, oxygen, cooling down the body, letting previous compressed parts of the lungs to react to the atmosphere are all variables that contribute to the process of contagious yawning. It's psychologically sound to be contagious on the premise that people are likely to breath irregularly when they are not focusing on their breathing.

SciShow is actually making a "correlation does not equal causation" fallacy because finding studies that show people are more alert after yawning may not be the cause for why we yawn, in fact if yawning does a lot of the body already, alertness may be a benefit while not the cause of why yawning is contagious.
